Class CoreStringUtils

java.lang.Object
org.krmdemo.techlabs.core.utils.CoreStringUtils
public class CoreStringUtils extends Object
Utility-class to work with strings, words and characters (some extension to JDK and StringUtils)

    • multiLine

      public static Collector<CharSequence, ?, String> multiLine()
      Just a short-cut of JDK-invocation: 
          Collectors.joining(System.lineSeparator())
      Returns:
      the Collector that join the stream of strings with System.lineSeparator()

    • joiningReversed

      public static <T> Collector<T, ?, CharSequence> joiningReversed()
      The same as Collectors.joining(CharSequence) with empty delimiter, but the elements of string are concatenated in reversed order.
      Note: Not use for large streams, because StringBuilder.insert(int, Object) is much slower than StringBuilder.append(Object) when the length of buffer is very big.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of input elements to the reduction operation
      Returns:
      the result as CharSequence (no extra copy of the result!)

    • joiningReversed

      public static <T> Collector<T, ?, CharSequence> joiningReversed(String delimiter)
      The same as Collectors.joining(CharSequence), but the elements of string are concatenated in reversed order.
      Note: Not use for large streams, because StringBuilder.insert(int, Object) is much slower than StringBuilder.append(Object) when the length of buffer is very big.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of input elements to the reduction operation
      Returns:
      the result as CharSequence (no extra copy of the result!)

    • joiningReversed

      public static <T> Collector<T, ?, CharSequence> joiningReversed(String delimiter, String prefix, String suffix)
      The same as Collectors.joining(CharSequence, CharSequence, CharSequence), but the elements of string are concatenated in reversed order.
      Note: Not use for large streams, because StringBuilder.insert(int, Object) is much slower than StringBuilder.append(Object) when the length of buffer is very big.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of input elements to the reduction operation
      Returns:
      the result as CharSequence (no extra copy of the result!)

    • hasNoNewLineAtTheEnd

      public static boolean hasNoNewLineAtTheEnd(String str)
      This method could be used to check whether the multi-line output ends with new-line-symbol(s), because ib most cases it's quite impossible to realize that fact visually (unless using different background).
      TODO: introduce a method to detect extra white-spaces before new-line like git-diff is doing
      Parameters:
      str - the string to check
      Returns:
      true if the passed line is not empty, and it does not end with new-line-symbol(s)
